How fast, how far, how much? The Ariya will be available for sale as early as the fall of 2021. Nissan says the range of 300 miles is a âpreliminary Nissan estimate for the long-range 2WD model.â Thatâs kind of a loaded statement because it tells us that there will be an all-wheel-drive version, which Nissan has confirmed. It also tells us that there will be varying models with different ranges, likely, costing more or less depending on how far you want to go on a single charge. That âaround $40,000 priceâ will probably be for the base model. Based on Nissanâs reinvention of itself, that base model will probably include some premium features with the option to add more. The 0-to-60 mph time should be under 5 seconds. The systemâs twin electric motors provide balanced, assured handling with sports car-level power.â Over-the-air firmware, Amazon AMZN, +3.01% Â Alexa, Android Auto, and Apple AAPL, +1.74% Â Car Play are all on board as are Nissanâs excellent Zero-Gravity seats. Itâs very minimalist â the 12.3-in screen has just one physical knob, and the rest of the controls appear to be via either touchscreen or haptic feedback. Thereâs also a prominent digital driver information display rather than a traditional gauge cluster. Itâs a sleek and clean look that we hope to see in future production Nissans.Safety In addition to the next generation ProPilot Assist 2.0, the Ariya gets a bunch of standard safety equipment. Nissan Safety Shield 360 is standard and that includes automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, rear automatic braking, lane-departure warning, blind-spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, high-beam assist, and Nissanâs around-view monitor.
